content.description:
This is a short and easy route below a couple of bolts. Mostly big ledges to grab and step onto. I made it a bit more challenging by avoiding easy stuff, but then you’re grabbing iffier holds. Watch out as some of the rock breaks off - I punched myself pretty hard when one came off. Wear helmets for sure, and use belay glasses if possible (or sunglasses at least if the belayer must look up). No dangerous-sized rocks came off.

Not sure who established the route or what its true name is.
content.protection: 2 bolts. Bring cordelette or slings to extend anchor over the edge
content.location: On the east side of the rock (shaded most of the day). The flat mostly continuous face with some obvious features in it. The easiest way to find it is to scramble up the backside nearby up to the first ledge (not to the peak) and then walk along the cliff until you see two obvious bolts.

climbs.name: The Pupil
climbs.fa: Giulio Del Piccolo, Dario Del Piccolo, Scott Fong

content.description: The obvious crack system on uphill side of the formation. The crux is at the top of the climb, where there is a near vertical detached block. from there it is an easy scramble to the summit of the Philosopher's Stone. There is a easy walk off down the backside of the formation.
content.protection: Trad gear. Camalots to the #3, but you could probably just get away with a #2, or even just nuts. There are lots of good placement options.

content.description: One-move-wonder over the geode-looking route next to The Pupil. Climb up the little cave, which is nice and clean rock, do a mildly difficult little overhang move (being very careful not to pull choss off the top), then you’ve topped out.
content.protection: Two bolts with rap rings (meant for The Pupil). Can run a rope from there or ideally use a static line and directional.
content.location: First lead climb The Pupil, then you can use those bolts, a long static line, and a directional to make a toprope anchor for this route. May not be worth your trouble. Does contain the single hardest / safest move we found on this rock (which isn’t saying a lot).

content.description:
No idea if I was actually the first ascent of this line, please post and rename if not etc.

The route is pretty easy 5.5-5.6 but has a single 5.7 crux over a bit of an overhang. Still, it is one of the scarier climbs I’ve been on recently, because the choss is absurd. Make sure the belayer is FAR from the wall and wear helmets! We pulled down a lot of rocks. If you can push through that, it’s decent fun.
content.location:
A line below the highest bolts on the stone, towards the south side of the rock (along the road). Use a 70m rope from those bolts and throw it down to the right side (when facing below from the bolts) of a tree. You will need to rap down with the rope to get it to the bottom. There is a short wall a bit below the anchor, then a class 4 scramble before the main drop.

This route will rub your rope. If you have a bunch of static line, you can skip the final short wall and put the anchor 30’ below the bolts, above the larger wall.
